text: They’re Earth’s mightiest heroes.
Marvel’s The Avengers have saved

the planet from alien invasion,
the Norse god of mischief,

and now face the angry robot
killing machine Ultron.

The Avengers combine amazing abilities
with some pretty amazing science.
(Reactions Intro)

Let’s start with everyone’s favorite
smartypants billionaire.
No, not Elon Musk - Tony Stark!, better known
as Iron Man after his original iron suit of armor.
Because iron is heavy and dense, Stark’s O-G
suit would have weighed around 150 pounds.
Not ideal.
Stark says he later upgraded to a gold-titanium
alloy, but that would actually make things worse.
That suit would probably weigh around
350 pounds, which might work
for the Hulk, but not Tony Stark.
Let’s have Raychelle explain.
“Stark’s suit is probably made of a nickel-titanium
alloy called nitinol. It’s strong, but light,
and can be re-formed after taking damage.
There may also be some graphite reinforced
with carbon fiber, which can take a lot of heat.
Useful if Iron Man doesn’t want to singe
his feet using those rocket boots.”
The power source inside Stark’s suit
has changed over the years.
The “arc reactor” that he designs is actually
a miniature nuclear power plant.
In Iron Man 2, the arc reactor depends on palladium.
But we learn that the palladium is slowly
poisoning him, so Stark does what any brilliant
scientist does, he creates a new element.
You’ve done that before right?
“Stark uses his homemade particle accelerator
to smash the nuclei of atoms together
to make a new type of atom.
It seems like movie magic, but that’s actually

pretty standard procedure for the
manufacturing of new elements.
Scientists have actually made more than
20 synthetic elements, so it’s not unbelievable

that Stark could have made a
new element to power his suit.”
But enough eccentric billionaires, let’s talk
Captain America and Black Widow.
According to the Marvel comics, both Black Widow
and Captain America have peak human abilities
— they’re super strong, have super quick reflexes,
tons of stamina and they age really slowly.
But they also can heal fast, though not as
fast as a certain other hairy Marvel hero.
How might this super healing work?
It’s probably has to do with white blood cells.
“In normal healing, a type of white blood cell
called a macrophage fights infections and
oversees the repair process. Macrophages
also send out chemical messengers called
growth factors that help repair wounds.
All these steps take between two to five
days in regular humans, but happen faster
in Black Widow and Captain America.
Their macrophages could be super productive,

pumping out more growth factors
to heal wounds more quickly.
Souped up white blood cells is not the Captain’s
only defense, he’s also got that awesome shield.
Cap’s shield protects him from everything:
bullets, grenades, lasers, supervillain
death rays and so on.
Most of that protection comes from good ol’ steel.
Steel is strong and rigid, allowing the captain
to throw his shield and have it knock off
multiple bad guys before it comes back to him.
But there’s more to the shield than just steel.
Conventional steel has a lot of super properties,
but it’s not a great shock absorber.
That’s why the captain’s shield’s steel
contains the imaginary mineral vibranium.
This material can absorb a near infinite amount

of vibrational energy without
getting too hot or melting.
But where is all that energy going?
Well, in the first Avengers movie, we see
Thor’s hammer strike the Captain’s shield.
The shockwave knocks both of them to
the ground, but the shield is just fine.
When Thor’s hammer hits the shield, you see a
huge flash of blue light, implying that vibranium
converts vibrational energy to light energy.

After all - they couldn’t put it
in a movie if it wasn’t true!
So there you go, Fearless Viewer.
Keep fighting the fight for Science!
And thanks to Sci-Pop for helping us
make this video happen!
Be sure to check out Jim Kakalios' book,
“The Physics of Superheroes” for more information.
We’ll put a link in the description.

you’d like to see us make?

We’d do it for you.
